entry.et: Middle English, pledge, recompense, from Anglo-French wage, gage, of Germanic origin; akin to Old High German wetti pledge wed

def.dt: :a payment usually of money for labor or services usually according to contract and on an hourly, daily, or piecework basis often used in plural
:the share of the national product attributable to labor as a factor in production
:recompense reward usually used in plural but singular or plural in construction the wages of sin is death Romans 6:23 (Revised Standard Version)

entry.et: Middle English, to offer surety, put up as a stake, hire, from Anglo-French *wager, gager, from wage

def.dt: :to engage in or carry on wage war wage a campaign
:to be in process of occurring the riot waged for several hours American Guide Series: Maryland
:a person who works for wages or salary
:a schedule of wage rates for related tasks
:the general level of wages in an industry or region
:a person dependent on wages or a salary for a livelihood
:a wage sufficient to provide the necessities and comforts essential to an acceptable standard of living
:the lowest wage paid or permitted to be paid
:a wage fixed by legal authority or by contract as the least that may be paid either to employed persons generally or to a particular category of employed persons
